title: Creating survival plot
code: # Load required libraries library(survSAKK) library(survival)  # Load lung data lung <- survival::lung  # Compute survival time in months and years lung$time.m <- lung$time/365.25*12 lung$time.y <- lung$time/365.25  # Create survival objects fit.lung.d <- survfit(Surv(time, status) ~ 1, data = lung) fit.lung.m <- survfit(Surv(time.m, status) ~ 1, data = lung) fit.lung.arm.m <- survfit(Surv(time.m, status) ~ sex, data = lung) fit.lung.arm.y <- survfit(Surv(time.y, status) ~ sex, data = lung)

title: Creating survival plot
code: # Single arm surv.plot(fit.lung.m) # Two arm surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m)

title: Creating survival plot
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           # Colour           col = c("cadetblue2", "cadetblue"),           # Title           main = "Kaplan-Meier plot",           # Axis label           xlab = "Time since treatment start (months)",           ylab = "Overall survival (probability)" )

title: Creating survival plot
code: # Choose legend position and names of the arms surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.position = "bottomleft",           legend.name = c("Male", "Female") ) # Choose legend position manually and add a legend title surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.position = c(18, 0.9),           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           legend.title = "Sex" )

title: Creating survival plot
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           xticks = seq(0, 36, by = 12),            yticks = seq(0, 1, by = 0.2) ) # Cut curve at 24 months surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           xticks = seq(0, 24, by = 6) )

previous_headings: Customisation of the survival plot > Font size
title: Creating survival plot
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           # Global adjustment           cex = 1.3,           risktable.name.position = -6,           risktable.title.position = -6 )

previous_headings: Customisation of the survival plot > Font size
title: Creating survival plot
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           main = "Kaplan-Meier plot",           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           legend.title = "Sex",           # Size of x-axis label           xlab.cex = 1.2,           # Size of y-axis label           ylab.cex = 1.2,           # Size of axis elements           axis.cex = 0.8,           # Size of the censoirng marks           censoring.cex = 1,           # Size of the legend title           legend.title.cex = 1.2,           # Size of the risktable           risktable.cex = 0.7,           # Size of the risktable name           risktable.name.cex = 0.9 )

previous_headings: Customisation of the survival plot > Label position x and y axis
what: Shift x and y axis label
title: Creating survival plot
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           xlab.pos = 6,           ylab.pos = 5 )

title: Creating survival plot
code: # Change the margins and shift the y axis label surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           # New margin area            margin.bottom = 6,           margin.left = 7,           margin.top = 1,           margin.right = 2,           # Define margin of the y-axis label           ylab.pos = 4 )

title: Creating survival plot
text: parameter time.unit can set follows: "day", "week", "month","year". Note following: time unit time.unit needs correspond time unit used calculate survival object fit. time.unit = "month" x ticks automatically chosen intervals 6 months. Whereas time.unit = "year" x ticks chosen intervals 1.
code: # Time unit of month surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           time.unit = "month",           y.unit = "probability",           legend.name = c("Male", "Female") ) # Time unit of year surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.y,           time.unit = "year",           y.unit = "percent",           legend.name = c("Male", "Female") )

title: Creating survival plot
text: Per default risk table provided Kaplan-Meier plot. provides information number patients risk different time points.

title: Creating survival plot
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           risktable = FALSE )

title: Creating survival plot
code: # Move risk table names and titles to the left surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("male", "female"),           risktable.name.position = -6,           risktable.title.position = -6 )

what: Risktable title, colour and label name
title: Creating survival plot
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           risktable.name = c("M", "F"),           risktable.col = TRUE,           risktable.title = "Number at risk",           risktable.title.font = 4,           risktable.title.col = "#E41A1C" )

title: Creating survival plot
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           risktable.censoring = TRUE)

title: Creating survival plot
text: section explains highlight specific quantile time point segment survival curve adjust segment annotation.

title: Creating survival plot
code: # Drawing a segment line for the median, which corresponds to 0.5 quantile surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           segment.quantile = 0.5 ) surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           segment.quantile = 0.5,           # Specifying time unit           time.unit = "month" ) # Drawing segment for the 0.75 quantile surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           segment.quantile = 0.75 )

title: Creating survival plot
code: #  Drawing a segment line at 12 months surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           time.unit = "month",           segment.timepoint = 12 )

title: Creating survival plot
text: parameter segment.annotation can take following values: c(x,y),"bottomleft", "left", "right", "top", "none"
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           segment.timepoint = 18,           segment.annotation = "top",           time.unit = "month" )

what: Segment title, font, size, and colour
title: Creating survival plot
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           col = c("cadetblue2", "cadetblue"),           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           time.unit = "month",           segment.quantile = 0.5,           segment.font = 10,           segment.main.font = 11,           segment.main = "Median PFS in months (95% CI)",           segment.cex = 0.8,           segment.annotation.col = "darkgray" )

what: Segment lines for different time points / quantile
title: Creating survival plot
text: Note segment.annotation needs set ‚Äúnone‚Äù. Otherwise code work.
code: # Several quantiles surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           segment.quantile = c(0.5, 0.25),           segment.annotation = "none",           time.unit = "month" ) # Several time points surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           segment.timepoint = c(6, 18),           segment.annotation = "none",           time.unit = "month" )

what: Segment line type, line width and text spacing
title: Creating survival plot
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           time.unit = "month",           segment.quantile = 0.5,           segment.lwd = 2,           segment.lty = "dashed",           segment.annotation.space = 0.1 )

title: Creating survival plot
text: Note option segment.confint = FALSE works two arms.
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           time.unit = "month",           segment.quantile = 0.5,           segment.confint = FALSE ) surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           time.unit = "month",           segment.timepoint = 18,           segment.confint = FALSE,           segment.annotation = "bottomleft" )

title: Creating survival plot
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           segment.quantile = 0.5,           conf.int = 0.8 ) surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           time.unit = "month",           segment.timepoint = 18,           y.unit = "percent",           conf.int = 0.9 )

title: Creating survival plot
text: three options parameter stat display statistics: logrank: gives p value log rank test calculated using survdiff{survival}. coxph: gives hazard ratio (HR) 95% CI conducted Cox proportional hazards regression using coxph{survival}.‚Å† coxph_logrank: combination logrank coxph.

title: Creating survival plot
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           stat = "logrank", )

title: Creating survival plot
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           stat = "coxph" )

title: Creating survival plot
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           stat = "coxph_logrank" )

what: Stat position, colour, text size, and text font
title: Creating survival plot
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           stat = "logrank",           stat.position = "right",           stat.col = "darkgrey",           stat.cex = 0.8,           stat.font = 3 )

what: Stat with redfined reference arm and confidence level
title: Creating survival plot
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           legend.name = c("Female","Male"),           stat = "coxph_logrank",           reference.arm = 2,           stat.conf.int = 0.80 )

title: Creating survival plot
text: next example ECOG performance status used stratification factor calculation statistics.
code: # Fit survival object with stratification  fit_lung_stratified <- survfit(Surv(time.m, status) ~ sex + strata(ph.ecog), data = lung)  surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           stat.fit = fit_lung_stratified,           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           stat = "coxph_logrank" )

title: Creating survival plot
text: following themes implemented: SAKK, Lancet, JCO, WCLC, ESMO
code: surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           theme = "ESMO") surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           theme = "Lancet")

title: Creating survival plot
text: present ways combine plots: via par(mfrow=c()) via split.screen()

title: Creating survival plot
code: # Creating 4 sub-plot par(mfrow=c(2,2))  # Plot 1 surv.plot(fit.lung.d) # Plot 2 surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,            time.unit = "month") # Plot 3 surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.y,            col = c("cadetblue2", "cadetblue"),            time.unit = "year",            stat = "coxph") # Plot 4 surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           # Cusomization of the survival plot           main = "Kaplan-Meier plot",           legend.name = c("Male", "Female"),           legend.title = "Sex",           xlab.cex = 1.2,           ylab.cex = 1.2,           axis.cex = 0.8,           censoring.cex = 1,           legend.title.cex = 1.2,           # Customization of the risktable           risktable.name.position = -9,           risktable.title.position = -9,           risktable.cex = 0.7) # reset the plotting area par(mfrow=c(1,1)) par(mfrow=c(2,1)) # Plot 1 surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,            col = c("cadetblue2", "cadetblue"),            time.unit = "month",            segment.quantile = 0.5) # Plot 2 surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,            col = c("cadetblue2", "cadetblue"),            time.unit = "month",            segment.timepoint = 6) par(mfrow=c(1,1))

title: Creating survival plot
code: split.screen(c(2,1)) #> [1] 1 2 screen(1) surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,            time.unit = "month",            segment.quantile = 0.5,            segment.confint = FALSE) screen(2) surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,            time.unit = "month",            segment.quantile = 0.75,            segment.confint = FALSE) close.screen(all = TRUE)

title: Creating survival plot
text: following examples show figure can exported png file report.
code: png(file = file.path("kaplan_meier_plot.png"),     width = 20,     height = 14,     units = "cm",     res = 300) surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           risktable.name.position=-4,           risktable.title.position=-4) dev.off()

title: Creating survival plot
text: bigger font size needed can done efficiently choosing different size output file.
code: png(file = file.path("kaplan_meier_plot_big_font.png"),     width = 20*0.7,     height = 14*0.7,     units = "cm",     res = 300) surv.plot(fit.lung.arm.m,           ylab = "Estimated survival \n (probability)",           risktable.name.position=-6.5,           risktable.title.position=-6.5) dev.off()

title: Authors and Citation
text: Vithersan Somasundaram. Author, maintainer. Katrin Gysel. Author, reviewer. Stefanie Hayoz. Contributor. SAKK, CC. Copyright holder, funder. SCTO, Statistics. Funder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Somasundaram V, Gysel K (2024). survSAKK: Create publication ready Kaplan-Meier plot. R package version 1.2.0, https://sakk-statistics.github.io/survSAKK/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {survSAKK: Create publication ready Kaplan-Meier plot},   author = {Vithersan Somasundaram and Katrin Gysel},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 1.2.0},   url = {https://sakk-statistics.github.io/survSAKK/}, }

title: Create publication ready Kaplan-Meier plot
text: survSAKK R package provides surv.plot() function, facilitating Kaplan-Meier survival analysis. Designed user-friendliness efficiency mind. Offering robust tool analysing survival data. utilises functionalites survival::survfit().

title: Create publication ready Kaplan-Meier plot
text: can install current version survSAKK GitHub Pages:
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("SAKK-Statistics/survSAKK",                          build_vignettes = TRUE,                          force = TRUE)

title: Create publication ready Kaplan-Meier plot
code: # Load required library library(survSAKK) library(survival)  # Fit survival object  fit <- survfit(Surv(lung$time/365.25*12, status) ~ sex, data = lung)  # Generate surival plot surv.plot(fit = fit,            time.unit = "month",           legend.name =  c("Male", "Female"))

title: Create publication ready Kaplan-Meier plot
code: # R Documentation ## survSAKK: Create publication ready Kaplan-Meier plot help("survSAKK-package")  ## Publication Ready Kaplan-Meier Plot help("surv.plot")

title: Create publication ready Kaplan-Meier plot
text: Webpage vignette: survSAKK
code: # Vignette vignette("surv.plot", package = "survSAKK")

title: Publication Ready Kaplan-Meier Estimator ‚Äî surv.plot
text: surv.plot(fit, ...) returns Kaplan-Meier survival time curves.

title: Publication Ready Kaplan-Meier Estimator ‚Äî surv.plot
text: fit object class survival::survfit containing survival data. reference.arm character string specifying reference arm comparison. time.unit character string specifying time unit used create fit object. Note: time.unit convert time fit object. Option include: "day", "week", "month","year". y.unit character string specifying unit y-axis. Option include: "probability", "percent". censoring.mark logical parameter indicating whether censoring events marked survival curves. Default TRUE. censoring.cex numeric value specifying size marks censored patients. Default 1.3. conf.int numeric value controlling confidence interval survival curves. Default 0.95, corresponding 95% confidence interval. Values 0 1 represent desired confidence interval. set 0, confidence intervals displayed. conf.band logical parameter indicating whether display confidence band survival curves. Default TRUE. conf.band.col colour used confidence band. Can accept single colour value vector colours. conf.band.transparent numeric value 0 1 controlling transparency confidence band. Default 0.25. conf.line.lty strings specifying line type confidence lines. Options include: "blank", "solid", "dashed", "dotted", "dotdash", "longdash", "twodash". Default "blank". conf.line.lwd numeric value specifying width confidence lines. conf.type Transformation type confidence interval. Options include: "log", "log-log", "plain", "logit", "arcsin". Default log-log. grid logical parameter specifying whether draw grid. Default FALSE. col colour used survival curves. Can accept single colour value  vector colours. main Title plot. sub Subtitle plot. Note: subtitle displayed risk table shown. xlab X-axis label. ylab Y-axis label. xticks numeric vector specifying ticks x-axis. Can specified seq(= , = , = ). : starting value : end value : number; increment sequence yticks numeric vector specifying ticks y-axis. Can specified seq(= , = , = ). : starting value : end value : number; increment sequence Note: always specified probability. xlab.pos Defines margin line X-axis label (xlab) displayed, starting 0 counting outwards. Default 1.5. ylab.pos Defines margin line Y-axis label (ylab) displayed, starting 0 counting outwards. Default 3. xlab.cex numeric value specifying size X-axis label. ylab.cex numeric value specifying size Y-axis label. cex numeric value specifying size text elements (labels, annotations, etc.). axis.cex numeric value specifying size axis elements. bty Determines style box drawn around plot. Options include: "n" ,"o","c","u". Default "n". lty string specifying line type curve(s). Options include: "blank", "solid", "dashed", "dotted", "dotdash", "longdash", "twodash". lwd numeric value specifying width line. legend logical parameter specifying whether display legend. default, legend displayed one arm. legend.position Position legend. Options include: "c(x,y)", "bottomright", "bottom", "bottomleft", "left"`, legend.name vector character string specifying name(s) arm(s). legend.cex numeric value specifying size legend text. legend.text.font Font style legend text. Possible values: 1 normal 2 bold 3 italic 4 bold italic legend.title Title legend. legend.title.cex numeric value specifying size legend title. segment.type numeric value specifying layout segment. Possible values: 1 full width 2 half width 3 vertical horizontal segment (default) segment.timepoint single value vector fixed time points drawn segment(s). segment.quantile single value vector fixed quantile drawn segment(s). Example: 0.5 corresponds median. segment.main Title segment text. segment.confint logical parameter specifying whether display confidence interval segment. NOTE: possible set segment.confint = FALSE two arms. Default TRUE. segment.annotation Position segment annotation. Options include: c(x,y),"bottomleft", "left", "right", "top", "none". segment.annotation.two.lines logical parameter force annotation displayed two lines even one arm. parameter effect one arm. Default: FALSE segment.annotation.col colour used segment annotation. Can accept single colour value vector colours. segment.annotation.space Spacing text units x-coordinates. segment.col colour used segment. Can accept single colour value. segment.lty strings specifying line type segment(s). Options include: "blank", "solid", "dashed", "dotted", "dotdash", "longdash", "twodash". segment.lwd numeric value specifying width segment line. segment.cex numeric value specifying size segment text size. segment.font numeric value specifying font face. Possible values: 1 plain 2 bold 3 italic 4 bold-italic segment.main.font numeric value specifying font face segment text. Possible values: 1 plain 2 bold 3 italic 4 bold-italic stat.fit object class survival::survfit containing survival data. Used calculation statistics, allowing add stratification factors. Note: specified fit object used stat. stat Statistics displayed plot. Options: "logrank" gives p value conducted logrank test using survdiff{survival}. tests difference two survival curves. "coxph"  gives hazard ratio (HR) CI (default: 95% CI)conducted Cox proportional hazards regression using coxph{survival}. Note: option works two arms. "coxph_logrank" combines hazard ratio (HR), CI (default: 95% CI) logrank test. Note: option works two arms. 'none' statistic displayed (default). Note: Confidence interval can adjusted argument stat.conf.int. stat.position Position stat displayed. Options include: c(x,y),"bottomleft", "left", "right", "top", "topright","bottomright", "none". stat.conf.int numeric value controlling confidence interval stat (hazard ratio). Default 0.95, corresponds 95% confidence interval. Values 0 1 represent desired confidence interval. stat.col colour used statistics text. Can accept single colour value vector colours. stat.cex numeric value specifying size `statistics text size. stat.font font face statistics Possible values: 1 plain 2 bold 3 italic 4 bold-italic risktable logical parameter indicating whether draw risk table. Default TRUE. risktable.censoring logical parameter indicating whether display number censored patients. Default FALSE. risktable.pos Defines margin line xlab displayed, starting 0 counting outwards. Default line 3. risktable.name Names arms risk table. risktable.cex numeric value specifying size risk table text size. risktable.col coulour used risk table. Can accept single colour value vector colours. Default black. Note: risktable.col = TRUE colours curves used. risktable.title Title risk table. risktable.title.font Font style risk table. Possible values: 1 normal 2 bold 3 italic 4 bold italic risktable.title.col colour used risk table title. Can accept single colour value. risktable.title.position numeric value specifying position title x-axis. risktable.title.cex numeric value specifying size risk table title size. risktable.name.cex numeric value specifying size risk table legend name size. risktable.name.font Font style risk table legend name(s). Possible values: 1 normal 2 bold 3 italic 4 bold italic risktable.name.col colour used risk table name. Can accept single colour value. risktable.name.position numeric value specifying position legend name(s) x-axis. margin.bottom Specifies bottom margin plotting area line units. Default 5. margin.left Specifies left margin plotting area line units. Default 6 (risktable) 4 (without risktable). margin.top Specifies top margin plotting area line units. Default 3. margin.right Specifies right margin plotting area line units. Default 2. theme Built-layout options. Options include: ("none", "SAKK", "Lancet", "JCO", "WCLC", "ESMO")

title: Publication Ready Kaplan-Meier Estimator ‚Äî surv.plot
code: require(survival)  require(survSAKK)  # Create survival object  fit <- survfit(Surv(lung$time/365.25*12, status) ~ sex, data = lung)  # Generate survival plots  surv.plot(fit = fit,    time.unit = "month",    legend.name =  c("male", "female"))
